The developments of World War II gave Scelha new opportunities for public service.
Prior to the Allied liberation of Home on June 9 1944, Scelha had returned to the capital
to work actively in the anti-fascist underground. And with Aleid© Be Gas peri and others,
he founded the Christian Democratic party as the successor to the old Popular party*
As I say, this background is vastly different from that of Gaetano Martino. Yet
Martino, strangely enough, grew up in a political atmosphere. His father was a staunch
Republican and the mayor of Messina for more than 20 years. But Martino elected to study
medicine, and he was graduated as a doctor from the University of Messina in 1923* He
then studied abroad — in England, France and Germany — and somewhere along the line he
decided to be a university professor.
Martino took the equivalent of our Ph.D. in 1928. Then came an unusual interlude.
He went off to Paraguay to teach physiology at the University of Asuncion before coming
back to Sicily to settle down as professor of bio-chemistry and general physiology at the
University of Messina. Except for the war period, when he took time out to serve as a
medical officer in the Italian navy, Martino advanced steadily in the academic world.
Eventually he was elected rector of the university by his faculty colleagues — a
position corresponding roughly, but not exactly, to that of president of an American
academy. His output of articles on the nervous system and nutrition for learned journals
was impressive. On the social side, he become president of the Messina Rotary club.
With this kind of record, it was understandable that pressures would he put on
Martino to enter politics after the fall of fascism and the end of the war. He says he
was reluctant to say yes when the Liberals asked him to help reconstitute that party in
Sicily in 1945. And he admits, candidly, that he had never been a militant anti-fascist.
But eventually, he joined the Liberal party and became a member of its national
committee. He was elected to the assembly that wrote Italy*s new republican constitution
in 1947 and he since has been elected twice to the Chamber of Deputies from Messina. He
had been vice president of the Chamber hut had never held a cabinet portfolio until Mario
ucelba named him education minister a year ago. He became foreign ra mister when Attilio
Piccioni resigned last fall.
You can understand from all this why the temptation is to say that the only things
Premier Scelha and Foreign Minister Martino have in common are their Sicilian origin and
their ages.
Scelha has spent many of his adult years in rough and tumble politics; Martino has
soent most of his adult life in the sophisticated atmosphere of a university. Scelha has
traveled little — in fact his recent official visit to England was his first trip to that
country — and he speaks only a little French, in addition to Italian. Martino is widely
traveled! speaks fair English, very good French and fluent Spanish. Scelha was a constant
foe of fascism! Martino, at least, accepted the regime of Mussolini. Ucelba, a devout
Catholic, has always been a member of a Roman Catholic partyj Martino, an ecually devout
Catholic, is a member of the Liberal party which historically has opposed the church in
politics.
Scelha is a much more cultured man than his critios would admit or than many of his
political associates realise, but Martino has written more than a hundred articles for
learned journals.
Still, the political fates brought these two Sicilians onto the same governmental
team in 1954, and the intervening months have shown that actually they have many things in
common.
